Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Twirl \Twirl\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {Twirled}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Twirling}.] [Cf. AS. [thorn]wiril a churn staff, a stirrer, flail, [thorn]weran, [=a][thorn]weran, to agitate, twirl, G. zwirlen, quirlen, to twirl, to turn round or about, quirl a twirling stick, OHG. dweran to twirl, stir. Cf. {Trowel}.] To move or turn round rapidly; to whirl round; to move and turn rapidly with the fingers. [1913 Webster]
See ruddy maids, Some taught with dexterous hand to twirl the wheel. --Dodsley. [1913 Webster]
No more beneath soft eve's consenting star Fandango twirls his jocund castanet. --Byron. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Twirl \Twirl\, v. i. To revolve with velocity; to be whirled round rapidly. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Twirl \Twirl\, n. 1. The act of twirling; a rapid circular motion; a whirl or whirling; quick rotation. [1913 Webster]
2. A twist; a convolution. --Woodward. [1913 Webster]

twirl n 1: a sharp bend in a line produced when a line having a loop is pulled tight [syn: {kink}, {twist}] 2: the act of rotating rapidly; "he gave the crank a spin"; "it broke off after much twisting" [syn: {spin}, {twist}, {twisting}, {whirl}] v 1: turn in a twisting or spinning motion; "The leaves swirled in the autumn wind" [syn: {swirl}, {twiddle}, {whirl}] 2: cause to spin; "spin a coin" [syn: {whirl}, {birl}, {spin}]
